p: In a pre-planned subgroup analysis for South Africa, compared with clinic ART, community-based ART increased viral suppression (60% vs 72%, RR 1·22, 95% CI 1·09–1·36) and the hybrid approach was non-inferior (60% vs 67%%, RR 1·12, 1·00–1·25; p non-inferiority=0·0026, RR >0·95). In South Africa, both community strategies significantly increased viral suppression among men: community-based ART (72%, RR 1·39, 95% CI 1·17–1·66) and the hybrid approach (65%, RR 1·26, 1·04–1·51), compared with standard of care (51%). There was significant interaction for gender and study group for both community-based ART (p=0·015) and the hybrid group (p=0·037) compared with clinic ART in the South African subset. The absolute increase in viral suppression was 20·4% (95% CI 10·0–30·3) for South African men in the community-based group compared with the clinic-based group ( appendix p 9).
